content: p. anne 2 nocturnal doesn’t belong to memory
question of foreigner: foreigner is in question, also, foreigner, putting the first question, puts me in question
third person, justice, foreigner, Levinas’ “birth of the question”
unbearable question, parricide question, threatens dogmatism of paternal logos
foreigner can be a parricide only when in the family
diamacheteon, heated combat, carry war into logoi, arguments, discourse [see SPOM p. xvii s’expliquer avec la mort, auseinanderstzen, argue, battle, come to grips w/ death]
pp. anne 8-10 “Derrida’s taking it to the limit when he works over a concept up to the point of its turning back toward the enigma that bears it”
madness, in Sophist, of the “foreign son,” parricide by a stranger
blindness & madness
in Sophist, madness described as being upside-down [Hegel > Marx]
[re: not knowing one’s own knowledge] leave the keys w/ the other to “unlock words from their enclosure” [AF p. 58 key is a seal]
pp. anne 12-4 you should interpret everything I haven’t said (my silences, what’s forbidden)
Socrates has characteristics of a foreigner [see p. 19]

foreigner’s pain: cannot speak the language, is w/out defense before the law, foreign to the language of hospitality > can we only welcome the foreigner if we impose the violence that he speaks our language?
violence of translation, foreign language imposition, for hospitality to be possible
at what point is a foreigner no longer foreign?
p. anne 20 acc. Nietzsche, w/out an experience, no ear to listen ~ [annihilation of trace?] “where nothing is heard nothing is there”
the right to hospitality commits a household, a line of descent, a family
a proper name is never purely individual
irreducible pervertibility in law of hospitality: the law of absolute hospitality commands a break with hospitality by right, w/ law or justice as rights [see p. 65 state perverts]
foreigner vs. barbarian (absolutely other does not have a name or family name)
question posed to the foreigner: “what is your name?”
what about unquestioning hospitality? more just, more loving to question or not to question? question of hospitality as question of question
“justice is heterogeneous to the law to which it is yet so close, from which in truth it is indissociable”
p. anne 28 “thought is in essence a force of mastery…breaking up the unknown to possess it, shed light on it, name it”
p. anne 30 is the anguish of aporia enough to prevent the process of growing accustomed?
p. anne 32 Derrida forces us to think, finally
p. anne 34 Derrida risks a discourse where nothing is planned, risks misunderstanding
put a city, an unconscious, on trial
read from another angle, not simply a triangle
Oedipus’ secret
p. anne 40 threshold of the night, clarity belongs to night (Patocka)… p. 50 it is out of the night that “what obsesses” can come to be spoken
hostis chain (hosti-pet-s, potis, potest, ipse, etc.)
to-and-fro btwn urgency of end-of-millenium and tradition from which we receive axioms, vocabulary, concepts: techno-political-scientific mutation obliges deconstruction
hospitality & email  (prosthetic apparatuses)
threshold, between familial and non-familial; email is or is not private?
literature is self-censoring, requires “competence”
inviolable immunity (the home) remains the condition of hospitality
state violates the inviolable, the home
I want to be master of my house, ipse, to receive whoever I like there
become virtually xenophobic to protect one’s hospitality
state techniques, like private spying & blackmail, threaten interiority of home, ipseity, integrity, cause purifying reactions, feeling of resentment [but???]
pp. anne 54-6 step beyond border, threshold, because inability to mark a stable territory provokes thought
the other becomes a hostile subject, I risk becoming their hostage.
host must elect, choose, filter, must have power, no hospitality w/out finitude: Gewalt, force of law
blessing of visibility and daylight also what police and politics demand
guest or parasite? a guest who is wrong, illegitimate
“what constitutes a space of controlled and circumscribed property is just what opens it to intrusion,” monad of a home has to have windows, has to let in
p. anne 64 hospitality threatens a world founded on transparency and quantification?
absolute porosity of techno-devices meant for keeping secrets, iterability that makes secrets accessible
pp. anne 66-8 Derrida’s political gesture: leave space for the essential [?]; [questions of politics arises anew in question of foreigner, of hospitality]

Kant against lying, duty to speak truth comes from freedom & pure intentionality of subject, but it introduces police everywhere (in our internal cellphones, our emails, most secret faxes of our private lives)
w/out right to lie > Kant subordinates rights of the home
publicity, pure morality = law, presence
hospitality’s infinite idea should resist the law itself

pp. anne 72-4 utopias from Marxism to fascism, turning into ideology, use implacable logic of economic efficiency, they claimed to be against, a nostalgia for a timeless fixity “that would keep in its hands the means of its exercise”
hospitality remains, like law, conditional, and thus conditioned on the unconditionality that is the basis of the law
becoming-law of justice
as if laws of hospitality (all specificity) define the impossibility of hospitality
unconditional, hyperbolical hospitality
p. anne 76 future, the absolutely surprising of what comes from the other
law of hospitality commands host gives arrivant, “new arrival,” an unconditional welcome; no anticipation
unconditional welcome of every other would include animals
aporia as the collision of two laws, antinomy; tragedy of destiny that 2 terms of antinomy are asymmetrical [the law above law & laws proper in plural]
p. anne 78 “Here I am” of the guest is traumatizing
politics of redemption troubled from inside by an inhumanity that closes up around its obsession
pervertibility (corruptibility) of hospitality—that it must actualize in laws
the father-son, the son as father
universal singularity opposed to plurality
categorical imperative (under erasure) of hospitality, unconditional; p. 83 unconditional w/out imperative, w/out duty, beyond economy and debt

motif.title: BEYOND ECONOMY / SURPLUS VALUE / GENERAL ECONOMY

content: there are 2 plurals, different at same time: 1) multiplicity, plural laws 2) One + a multiplicity, One + n [plus d’un]
the great law of hospitality, of the singular, is One + n, vs. the law of plurality, which is a law of differentiation, multiplicity, distribution
One + n, the antinomic addition, adds conditional laws to unconditional law of hospitality, Derrida’s even ok w/ using phrase “categorical imperative” (kept under erasure)
“at this very moment”: antinomy of laws in the plural and absolutely singular law
hospitality must not pay a debt
place Kant’s categorical imperative under erasure, under epochē
law (is always) laid down, laid down against some nature, an instituted thesis > laws that command, impassive, oversees behind glass, tomb of glass
law always instituted against, an instituted thesis
two sources of sighs, two nostalgias, their dead ones and their language > return home, or exiles find home in language
foreigner at birth (language) and burial

p. anne 88 “madness in the relationship to the mother,” the very possibility of madness; p. 92 “the essence of madness must be related to the essence of hospitality, in the area of this uncontrollable outburst toward the one who is closest,” mother tongue as metaphor for “being-at-home in the other”
language gives the fantasy of property

“language is also the experience of expropriation, of an irreducible exappropriation” makes us all wandering Jews, mother tongue is the tongue of the other [universalizes election], desert in all of us
language most mobile, immovable, the absolute ground of all displacements
Oedipus gives the most poisoned gift, the deprivation of mourning, gives the mourning of mourning, no time of mourning, a respite of infinite time [for Freud, Oedipus’ gift is society]
p. anne 94 [from mother to violence] eruption of violence which borrows its madness from mother, substituted for proximity, from hospitality to hostility > terrorism, hostage wars
reticence: deliberate keeping quiet
the sacred, that which cannot be spoken, the most impure, the secret that cannot be violated by speech, the motion of logos

motif.title: UNSCATHED / SAFE / SACRED / GUARD / SECURITY / KEEP

content: Oedipus conducts his own funeral in secret
p. anne 98 Levinas: “essence of language is friendship and hospitality”
security, safety of a city: borne through transmission of the secret

motif.title: UNSCATHED / SAFE / SACRED / GUARD / SECURITY / KEEP

content: eyes of God: law placard

delay and haste, halting and hastening, rhythm of Oedipus’ journey; p. 127 infinite speed contracted into an absolute halt or haste, precipitation because delay, instant of an instant that is canceled out > thus always late & precipitous re: hospitality
p. anne 102 the dead, the corpse, are the most easily read, manipulated [?]
[Oedipus’ dying words] “last time I see lightless light,” Oedipus weeps for tangible light
[on Oedipus’ final mourning] he’s deprived of something in secrecy [of light?], an encrypting of encrypting, in the crypt the address is cryptic
Oedipus is twice encrypted, 1st in dying, 2<sup><small>nd</small></sup> in hiding his death > by demanding he be kept dead, he announces a piece of blackmail

motif.title: UNSCATHED / SAFE / SACRED / GUARD / SECURITY / KEEP

content: Oedipus finds himself bound by an oath to which he is asymmetrically committed, committed before the god; when Theseus invokes the oath, everyone is hostage to the dead man
Theseus, with Oedipus’ burial secret, becomes a retained hostage, a detained addressee
subject as a host and a hostage
we are always in some way late; “the consciousness only anticipates, ever, one delay too many”
p. anne 110 what doesn’t belong to you, highest risk. what you do not possess is what obsesses you
mourning is not allowed without a fixed (arrêté) place, monument, determinable topos, stopping point (arrêt) > promised w/out taking place, only possible mourning is an impossible one

p. anne 114 crypt, vault [voute] has a relation to casting spells [envoutement]; pp. 124-26 having a spell cast is enclosure beneath a vault—dematerialization of Internet end of spell? no, there’s spell, encrypting in techno-communication
Antigone says that Oedipus desired his fate
“no fixed address” of death, no phenomenal exteriority, interiority of the heart, nocturnal secret (a suffering both intimate & infinite)
Oedipus first man (Hegel), last man (Nietzsche)
from Oedipus at Colonus: oath (Orkos) hears everything
entering is crossing the threshold, not only approaching or coming
master: prisoner of his place and power
“impossibility of that ‘at the same time’ is at the same time what happens, once and every time, it is what is going to happen, what always happens”
the guest becomes the host’s host
infinite speed contracted into an absolute halt or haste, precipitation because delay, instant of an instant that is canceled out > thus always late & precipitous re: hospitality
Klossowski: stranger on the horizon like a liberator
Klossowski: surprise in the instant
p. anne 130 what happens when humans are dispossessed of their interiority?
we let ourselves be interrogated by certain figures of the foreigner, “what?” “who?”
question of foreigner, question of response and responsibility
stranger/foreigner by way of “social class”
speaking the same language a matter of ethos, not just linguistic operation
keeping silent a modality of possible speaking
absolute and conditioned hospitality must pervert each other (capacity for perversion irreducible) [see p. 147]
Levinas says language is hospitality
absolute hospitality offers gift w/out reservations
absolute, hyperbolical, unconditional hospitality suspends language, a particular determinant one, and even the address to the other
always threatened by this dilemma: 1) when unconditional hospitality is circumscribed by economy of circle  (law, duty) [vs. ring?] 2) when unconditional hospitality dispenses w/ law
economy of circle [vs. ring?]
p. anne 136 deconstruction leads to uncanny at heart of the most familiar, where “all we had seen was fire”

technological prostheses, whose refinements are unlimited in principle > still give fantasy of auto-nomy, auto-affection: is there hospitality w/out this, w/out auto-affection, the privileged figure of hearing oneself speak?
proper name in its pure possibility: it’s to you yourself, I say: “come,” “enter”
urgent contemporary matters [new technologies] not only bring classical structures into present, they seem to deconstruct these inheritances of themselves
through philosophy and literature we interrogate our language
p. anne 140 hyperbole always comes first of all as a question
in Algeria, 1919, Muslims refuse citizenship that would relinquish religious laws (personal status)
p. anne 148 disseminating logic of death: because it can be manipulated by everyone, easily [?]

how could there be a perfectible, concrete politics? [can’t be, but] intervene in condition of hospitality (unprecedented historical situations) in name of unconditional, even if it seems inaccessible like Kantian regulative idea, but also inaccessible for structural reasons, “barred” by internal contradictions
p. anne 152 a place of haunting has no ghosts, ghosts come where they are excluded, death haunts us by remaining unthought
narratives of hospitality testify without end in our memory
